comment.narrative:
Incomplete inventory of in service equipment and inventories of PCB waste stockpiles cross contaminated equipment and contaminated sites
No formal consolidated PCB information system or associated reporting capability
Absence of capability to costeffectively identify and categorize PCB contaminated materials acting as a major barrier to inventory development and tracking Currently no laboratory is equipped to specifically undertake PCB analysis

The national inventory of 2344 electric transformers completed in 2014 indicated that 293 electric transformers were suspected to contain oil contaminated with PCBs No capacitor was found to be contaminated with PCBs
A total of 61 staff and technicians drawn from Rwanda Energy Group former EWSA REMA and Rwanda Standard Board former Rwanda Bureau of Standard were trained in October 2014 on how to sample and test for PCBs using the ChlorNOil test kits by the national consultant
Using ChlorNOil test kits 461 transformers were tested which included 293 suspected transformer and 168 transformers that were not suspected to confirm the contaminationnoncontamination with PCBs
Results of ChlorNOil tests indicated that 151 transformers of the 293 suspected transformers which approximately weigh 498 tonnes are contaminated with PCBs of more than 50ppm None of the nonsuspicious 168 transformers contained more than 50ppm PCBs
Draft ToR necessary to hire an international consultant to support in quantitative analysis have been developed and are now being reviewed before advertisement can be done by October 2015
The international consultant will provide technical support to the national laboratory of RSB to be able to undertake quantitative analysis of the oil of the 151 PCB containing transformers gt 50 ppm as well as water and soil samples from around leaking transformers that contain PCBs ata concentration of more than 50ppm
The data management tool that was established by updating the 2005 PCB database has been populated with the results of ChlorNOil tests The database provides information about contaminated equipment in operation existing PCB stockpiles and contaminated sites The database will continue to be updated on a regular basis by the Rwanda Energy Group REG limited former EWSA Plans are underway to make the database publicly available in REMA and REG websites once quantitative testing is completed
Assessment of five national laboratories capacities to undertake analysis of PCBs and other POPs chemicals has been done and a report has been prepared in September 2014 The report recommends measures for upgrading the five laboratories capacity to analysis POPsPCBs in different media
A guideline for regular inspection monitoring and continuous updating of the PCBs inventory was produced and printed in 2015 and is being widely disseminated to REG and other PCBs holders

description.narrative: 21PCB legislation and technical guidance developed and implemented

Regulations requiring registration labeling and status reporting of potential all PCB and PCB containing materials in use end of 2010
Adoption of appropriate hazardous waste classification of PCBs and PCB contaminated materials in 2010
Enactment of legal ban on new use reuse trade import and export of PCBs and PCB contaminated equipment and materials in 2010
Legal measures allowing unrestricted regulatory access to information and locations that may have PCBs wastes stockpiles PCB containing equipment and site contamination in 2010

comment.narrative:
No current regulations requiring declarationreportingunique identification by holders of presence of PCB waste stockpiles or PCB containing equipment
PCB waste classification not well defined in current waste management regulations allowing potential avoidance of proper management
No regulation of PCB trade use and importexport
Uncontrolled trade in contaminated PCB equipment occurs including export of stockpiles and waste and import of used PCB equipment
ReUse of PCBs occurs
In appropriate declassification of PCB contaminated equipment occurs
Legal barriers on the ability of authorities to inspect and access sites

A comprehensive national regulatory registry of all PCB containing equipment in service that is maintained and updated such that its status and fate can be tracked
Explicit inclusion of high concentration PCB wastes as priority hazardous wastes in national waste management legislationregulations
Consistency of these with applicable international standards and the Basel Convention on transboundary movement of hazardous waste
Effective implementation and enforcement of use reuse trade import and export bans including ensuring trade in scrapped contaminated PCB equipment and import of used PCB equipment is eliminated
Allowance in practice of access by mandated regulatory authorities to sites potentially containing or contaminated by PCBs including rights to initiate assessment

A PCBs Law which provides the legal framework for the management disposal and phaseout of PCBs in Rwanda in line with Basel and Stockholm Conventions provisions and requirements has been developed and validated by the stakeholders
The draft PCB law is currently being reviewed by the Rwanda Law Reform Commission before official submission to Ministry of Justice through the Ministry of Natural Resources for enactment into a law by the Parliament

No current information products or programs
Limited active educational efforts or tools available
Key stakeholders generally have limited awareness of the issue or actions required of them to address it

Widely accessible current information on PCBs and ongoing management activities

REMA has produced a capacity building plan to raise public awareness of the environmental and health effects of exposure to PCBs
A training manual and information dissemination materials posters brochures and flyers for raising awareness about the health and environmental effects of exposure to PCBs have been developed and are now being disseminated in ongoing public awareness campaigns All downloadable tools will be made available on the REMA web site
During this reporting period the following workshopsseminars have taken place
1 A training of 32 journalists from 32 different media houses Nov 2014
2 A training of 30 District Environmental facilitators 25 representatives from REG Ltd 5 REMA staff from the Department in charge of Environmental regulation and pollution control as well as a representative from RSB Oct 2014
3 14 training sessions in 14 secondary schools in which 710 students and teachers 390 55 male and 320 45 female across Western Northern and Southern provinces were trained in June 2015
4 A training of 55 staff from 55 NGOs dealing with Environment and Natural Resources across Rwanda were trained in JuneJuly 2015
REMAs department of environmental education and mainstreaming is currently spearheading the review of the education curriculum to ensure that environmental issues are incorporated in primary and secondary education Chemicals management including PCBs and POPs are some of the new topics that will be proposed
Collaboration between REMA and institutions of higher learning through this project has enhanced sensitization on POPsPCBs among teaching staff Institutions of higher learning are actively participating in the project steering committee and in the project technical team This has contributed towards the department of Chemistry at University of Rwanda integrating sessions on POPs and PCB management in existing courses and recommending the review of the curriculum on dynamic equilibrium for fourth year degree students to include Sustainable Chemical Management including POPsPCBs

comment.narrative:
Limited trained capability in the safe handling of PCB contaminated materials and general absence of such capability among holders of PCBs and private service providers
Some PCB containing electrical equipment transformers are in critical applications and have long remaining service lives
Current practices involving replacement of oil do not meet international standards and result in retention of PCB contaminated equipment
No identified and secured stockpiles with most stockpiles likely being exported as scrap but leaving residual contamination in the form of waste materials and contaminated soils at unknown locations
No assigned responsibility for hazardous waste management generally and PCBs in particular

Fully operational service provider capacity to support the securing of PCB waste stockpiles and transport to the designated national facility or export for disposal
